perturbation.original_text: Payment  to CSA no later than thirty (30) days after receipt of invoice from CSA. CSA shall submit  invoice to the Company no later than thirty (30) days after Company provides CSA with the list of the sales of Product (containing the Property with such supporting information that may be required or requested to be disclosed).
perturbation.changed_text: Payment  to CSA no later than sixty (60) days after receipt of invoice from CSA. CSA shall submit  invoice to the Company no later than ninety (90) days after Company provides CSA with the list of the sales of Product (containing the Property with such supporting information that may be required or requested to be disclosed).
perturbation.explanation: The original contract states the company needs to pay CSA no later than 30 days after receipt of invoice from CSA. In addition, CSA shall submit invoice to the company no later than 30 days after the company provides CSA with the sales list. The modified text extends the payment deadlines, which could violate UK late payment regulations, especially if the original 30-day terms were already borderline. Depending on the size of the company, the industry and the agreed terms in the primary agreement, extending the payment terms to 60 and 90 days respectively may be considered an unfair imposition and create a legal contradiction.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Late Payment of Commercial Debts (Interest) Act 1998 (UK)

perturbation.original_text: Talent  shall have seven (7) days following receipt of such Materials or any part thereof displaying  the intended use of the Property to review and for CSA to provide to Company written approval for such use.
perturbation.changed_text: Talent  shall have three (3) days following receipt of such Materials or any part thereof displaying  the intended use of the Property to review and for CSA to provide to Company written approval for such use.
perturbation.explanation: The original agreement gives Talent 7 days to review materials. This alteration reduces the review period to 3 days. Depending on the complexity of the materials and the specific terms implied by 'reasonable time' within UK contract law, reducing the review period to three days could be deemed unreasonable, particularly if it consistently prevents Talent from conducting a thorough review, thus conflicting with the implied term of good faith and fair dealing in contract performance.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied term of 'reasonable time' and good faith in UK Contract Law

perturbation.original_text: Talent agrees that Company shall, for a period of nine (9) months (Sell-Off Period) following the effective date of termination, have the right to continue to sell Product bearing  the Property and/or utilize advertising materials and collateral bearing the Property. Such sales and use shall be made subject to all the provisions of this Agreement and in particular clause 4 hereof.
perturbation.changed_text: Talent agrees that Company shall, for a period of eighteen (18) months (Sell-Off Period) following the effective date of termination, have the right to continue to sell Product bearing  the Property and/or utilize advertising materials and collateral bearing the Property. Such sales and use shall be made subject to all the provisions of this Agreement and in particular clause 4 hereof.
perturbation.explanation: The original agreement allows a 9-month sell-off period post-termination. Extending this to 18 months could be considered an unreasonable restraint of trade under UK law. If the extended period significantly limits Talent's ability to exploit their brand and likeness with other ventures, especially within a specific market like property training, it might be deemed an unenforceable term. A court would assess whether the extended period is necessary to protect the company's legitimate business interests and whether it is unduly restrictive on Talent.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Doctrine of Restraint of Trade (UK Contract Law)
